1.title: Abstruse
1.subtitle: Difficult to understand; obscure
1.description: The philosopher's work was filled with abstruse concepts that only a few scholars could grasp.

2.title: Cynosure
2.subtitle: A person or thing that is the center of attention or admiration
2.description: At the gala, the renowned artist was the cynosure of all eyes.

3.title: Desultory
3.subtitle: Lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm; casual
3.description: His desultory efforts at studying meant he was ill-prepared for the exam.

4.title: Ebullient
4.subtitle: Cheerful and full of energy
4.description: Her ebullient personality was infectious, lifting everyone's spirits.

5.title: Farrago
5.subtitle: A confused mixture
5.description: The report was a farrago of unsubstantiated claims and unrelated facts.

6.title: Ignominious
6.subtitle: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame
6.description: The team suffered an ignominious defeat, losing by a huge margin.

7.title: Kenophobia
7.subtitle: An abnormal fear of voids or empty spaces
7.description: His extreme discomfort in large, open rooms suggested a touch of kenophobia.

8.title: Lachrymose
8.subtitle: Tearful or given to weeping
8.description: The movie's ending was so tragic that it left the audience in a lachrymose state.

9.title: Miasma
9.subtitle: A noxious or poisonous atmosphere; an oppressive or unpleasant atmosphere
9.description: The old factory emitted a miasma of foul-smelling smoke.

10.title: Nugatory
10.subtitle: Of no value or importance; useless or futile
10.description: His arguments were ultimately nugatory, having no impact on the judge's decision.

11.title: Obstreperous
11.subtitle: Noisy and difficult to control
11.description: The teacher struggled to manage the obstreperous class during the field trip.

12.title: Panegyric
12.subtitle: A public speech or published text in praise of someone or something
12.description: The documentary was a glowing panegyric to the late civil rights leader.

13.title: Querulous
13.subtitle: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner
13.description: The elderly man was known for his querulous disposition, always finding fault.

14.title: Redolent
14.subtitle: Strongly reminiscent or suggestive of something; fragrant or smelling strongly of something
14.description: The old bookstore was redolent of aged paper and leather.

15.title: Sartorial
15.subtitle: Relating to tailoring, clothes, or style of dress
15.description: His impeccable sartorial choices always made a strong impression.

16.title: Tergiversate
16.subtitle: Make conflicting or evasive statements; equivocate
16.description: When questioned, the politician began to tergiversate, avoiding a direct answer.

17.title: Ubiquitous
17.subtitle: Present, appearing, or found everywhere
17.description: In the digital age, screen time has become an almost ubiquitous part of daily life.

18.title: Vituperative
18.subtitle: Bitter and abusive
18.description: The public debate quickly devolved into vituperative exchanges between the candidates.

19.title: Waggish
19.subtitle: Humorous in a playful, mischievous, or facetious manner
19.description: His waggish remarks often brought smiles to his colleagues' faces.

20.title: Xenodochial
20.subtitle: Friendly to strangers (an archaic or rare word)
20.description: The isolated community was surprisingly xenodochial, welcoming travelers with open arms.

21.title: Ylem
21.subtitle: (in the Big Bang theory) the primordial matter of the universe from which all later matter was formed
21.description: In the theory of the Big Bang, all matter originated from a singular ylem.

22.title: Zephyr
22.subtitle: A soft, gentle breeze
22.description: A gentle zephyr rustled the leaves, providing a welcome respite from the summer heat.

23.title: Anathema
23.subtitle: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes; a formal curse by a Pope or a council of the Church
23.description: For environmentalists, deforestation is an anathema.

24.title: Brocade
24.subtitle: A rich fabric, typically silk, woven with a raised pattern, typically with gold or silver thread
24.description: The antique armchair was upholstered in a beautiful floral brocade.

25.title: Cacography
25.subtitle: Bad handwriting or spelling
25.description: The student's essay was almost illegible due to his atrocious cacography.

26.title: Demagoguery
26.subtitle: An appeal to people's desires and prejudices rather than to their rational thought
26.description: The politician's speech was dismissed as pure demagoguery, designed to incite fear.

27.title: Effulgent
27.subtitle: Shining brightly; radiant
27.description: The bride walked down the aisle, her face effulgent with joy.

28.title: Flummox
28.subtitle: Perplex (someone) deeply; bewilder
28.description: The complex instructions completely flummoxed him.

29.title: Garrulous
29.subtitle: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters
29.description: The garrulous old man told everyone his life story in the waiting room.

30.title: Hegemony
30.subtitle: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others
30.description: The struggle for regional hegemony led to decades of conflict.

31.title: Inchoate
31.subtitle: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary
31.description: His ideas for the novel were still inchoate, a vague outline in his mind.

32.title: Jejune
32.subtitle: Naive, simplistic, and superficial; dry and uninteresting
32.description: The new intern's proposals were rather jejune, lacking real substance.

33.title: Kakistocracy
33.subtitle: A system of government which is run by the worst, least qualified, or most unscrupulous citizens
33.description: Critics argued that the current administration was a clear example of a kakistocracy.

34.title: Lassitude
34.subtitle: A state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy
34.description: The summer heat brought on a feeling of overwhelming lassitude.

35.title: Mellifluous
35.subtitle: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear
35.description: Her mellifluous voice was perfect for soothing restless children.

36.title: Nadir
36.subtitle: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization; the astronomical point opposite the zenith
36.description: His career reached its nadir after the scandalous revelations.

37.title: Obfuscate
37.subtitle: Render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
37.description: Some politicians deliberately obfuscate the truth to confuse voters.

38.title: Pecuniary
38.subtitle: Relating to or consisting of money
38.description: He faced significant pecuniary difficulties after losing his job.

39.title: Quisling
39.subtitle: A traitor who collaborates with an enemy occupying force
39.description: He was branded a quisling for cooperating with the invading army.

40.title: Recalcitrant
40.subtitle: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline
40.description: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the teacher's instructions.

41.title: Serendipity
41.subtitle: The occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
41.description: It was pure serendipity that she stumbled upon the rare book at a small shop.

42.title: Truculent
42.subtitle: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
42.description: His truculent behavior made it difficult to resolve the conflict peacefully.

43.title: Unctuous
43.subtitle: Excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily
43.description: The salesman's unctuous compliments made her feel uneasy.

44.title: Verisimilitude
44.subtitle: The appearance of being true or real
44.description: The novel achieved remarkable verisimilitude in its depiction of 19th-century London.

45.title: Weltanschauung
45.subtitle: A particular philosophy or view of life; a worldview
45.description: His experiences shaped his unique weltanschauung on human nature.

46.title: Xenophobia
46.subtitle: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries
46.description: Education is crucial in combating the rise of xenophobia.

47.title: Yips
47.subtitle: A state of nervous tension that affects an athlete's performance (especially in golf)
47.description: The golfer suffered from the yips during the crucial final putt.

48.title: Zenith
48.subtitle: The time at which something is most powerful or successful; the point in the sky directly above an observer
48.description: At the zenith of his career, he was considered the greatest living artist.

49.title: Apotheosis
49.subtitle: The highest point in the development of something; the elevation of someone to divine status
49.description: Her performance was the apotheosis of acting, flawless and captivating.

50.title: Bane
50.subtitle: A cause of great distress or annoyance
50.description: Excessive bureaucracy was the bane of his existence in the government.

51.title: Cynosure
51.subtitle: A person or thing that is the center of attention or admiration
51.description: The new architectural masterpiece became the cynosure of the city.

52.title: Diaphanous
52.subtitle: Light, delicate, and translucent
52.description: She wore a diaphanous silk scarf that shimmered in the sunlight.

53.title: Esoteric
53.subtitle: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest
53.description: The ancient text was filled with esoteric symbols and references.

54.title: Fulsome
54.subtitle: Complimentary or flattering to an excessive degree; of large size or quantity
54.description: Her fulsome praise felt insincere and over-the-top.

55.title: Glabrous
55.subtitle: (especially of a plant or animal) having no hairs or other covering; smooth
55.description: The scientist observed the perfectly glabrous surface of the rare plant leaf.

56.title: Homily
56.subtitle: A sermon; a tedious moralizing lecture or discourse
56.description: The principal's assembly turned into a long homily about the importance of punctuality.

57.title: Ignoble
57.subtitle: Not honorable in character or purpose
57.description: His actions were driven by an ignoble desire for revenge.

58.title: Jocose
58.subtitle: Playful or humorous
58.description: His jocose comments always lightened the mood during tense meetings.

59.title: Kerfuffle
59.subtitle: A commotion or fuss, especially one caused by conflicting views
59.description: There was a bit of a kerfuffle when the band arrived late for the concert.

60.title: Lagniappe
60.subtitle: Something given as a bonus or extra gift
60.description: The street vendor gave him an extra pastry as a lagniappe.

61.title: Meticulous
61.subtitle: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
61.description: The watchmaker was meticulous in assembling the tiny gears.

62.title: Nostrum
62.subtitle: A medicine, especially one that is not considered effective, prepared by an unqualified person; a pet scheme or remedy, especially one for social or political ills
62.description: The politician's proposed solution was dismissed as a mere nostrum.

63.title: Opprobrious
63.subtitle: Expressing scorn or criticism
63.description: He faced opprobrious remarks from the angry crowd.

64.title: Pellucid
64.subtitle: Translucently clear; easily understood; limpid
64.description: Her writing style was remarkably pellucid, making complex concepts easy to grasp.

65.title: Quiddity
65.subtitle: The inherent nature or essence of someone or something
65.description: He tried to understand the quiddity of human existence through philosophical inquiry.

66.title: Ratiocinate
66.subtitle: Form judgments by a process of reasoning; reason
66.description: He urged his colleagues to ratiocinate carefully before making a final decision.

67.title: Salubrious
67.subtitle: Health-giving; healthy
67.description: The mountain air was surprisingly salubrious after weeks in the polluted city.

68.title: Tendentious
68.subtitle: Expressing or intending to promote a particular cause or point of view, especially a controversial one
68.description: The article was criticized for its tendentious reporting, clearly biased.

69.title: Unctuous
69.subtitle: Excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily
69.description: The salesman's unctuous demeanor made customers suspicious.

70.title: Vatic
70.subtitle: Describing or predicting what will happen in the future
70.description: The ancient prophecy proved to be vatic, foretelling future events with accuracy.

71.title: Wizened
71.subtitle: Shriveled or wrinkled with age
71.description: The old woman's face was wizened from years of exposure to the sun.

72.title: Xerophthalmia
72.subtitle: Abnormal dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, which may result in damage to the eye if untreated. It is caused by vitamin A deficiency.
72.description: In some developing countries, xerophthalmia is a significant public health concern due to dietary deficiencies.

73.title: Yeoman
73.subtitle: A man holding and cultivating a small landed estate; a hardworking, diligent, or loyal worker
73.description: He performed his duties with yeoman service, always reliable and dedicated.

74.title: Zugzwang
74.subtitle: (in chess and other games) a situation in which a player is forced to make a disadvantageous move or one that worsens their position
74.description: In the final moments of the chess game, he realized he was in zugzwang, with no good moves left.

75.title: Abscond
75.subtitle: Leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest
75.description: The accountant tried to abscond with the company's funds.

76.title: Bilk
76.subtitle: Obtain or withhold money from (someone) by deceit or without justification; cheat or defraud
76.description: The con artist attempted to bilk unsuspecting tourists out of their money.

77.title: Chicanery
77.subtitle: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose
77.description: The political campaign was rife with accusations of chicanery.

78.title: Disingenuous
78.subtitle: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does
78.description: His apologies sounded disingenuous, as if he didn't truly mean them.

79.title: Eschew
79.subtitle: Deliberately avoid using; abstain from
79.description: He decided to eschew social media for a month to focus on his well-being.

80.title: Foment
80.subtitle: Instigate or stir up (an undesirable or violent sentiment or course of action)
80.description: Their speeches were designed to foment discontent among the workers.

81.title: Gaffe
81.subtitle: An unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment to its originator; a blunder
81.description: The politician made a huge gaffe during the press conference.

82.title: Harridan
82.subtitle: A strict, bossy, or belligerent old woman
82.description: The children feared the stern harridan who lived next door.

83.title: Incontrovertible
83.subtitle: Not able to be denied or disputed
83.description: The evidence presented was incontrovertible, proving his innocence.

84.title: Jettison
84.subtitle: Throw or drop (something) from an aircraft or ship; abandon or discard (someone or something that is no longer wanted)
84.description: The company decided to jettison the failing product line.

85.title: Kismet
85.subtitle: Destiny; fate
85.description: They believed it was kismet that brought them together after all those years.

86.title: Lascivious
86.subtitle: Feeling or revealing an overt and often offensive sexual desire
86.description: His lascivious comments made the employees uncomfortable.

87.title: Misanthrope
87.subtitle: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society
87.description: The old hermit was a notorious misanthrope, shunning all social contact.

88.title: Nefarious
88.subtitle: Wicked or criminal
88.description: The supervillain plotted a nefarious scheme to take over the world.

89.title: Obeisance
89.subtitle: Deferential respect; a bow or curtsy
89.description: The subjects made deep obeisance to the king.

90.title: Pugnacious
90.subtitle: Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight
90.description: The pugnacious boxer was always ready for a challenge.

91.title: Quixotic
91.subtitle: Extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
91.description: His quixotic quest to eliminate poverty overnight was admirable but naive.

92.title: Recondite
92.subtitle: Dealing with very profound, difficult, or abstruse subject matter
92.description: The professor lectured on recondite theories that few in the audience understood.

93.title: Scurrilous
93.subtitle: Making or spreading scandalous claims about someone with the intention of damaging their reputation
93.description: The politician was a victim of a scurrilous smear campaign.

94.title: Temerity
94.subtitle: Excessive confidence or boldness; audacity
94.description: He had the temerity to interrupt the CEO during his presentation.

95.title: Unfathomable
95.subtitle: Incapable of being fully explored or understood
95.description: The depths of the universe remain largely unfathomable to human understanding.

96.title: Vicissitude
96.subtitle: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant
96.description: He faced many vicissitudes in his long and challenging career.

97.title: Wallow
97.subtitle: Roll about or lie in mud or water; (of a person) indulge in an unrestrained way in (something that creates a pleasurable sensation)
97.description: He spent the afternoon wallowing in self-pity after his defeat.

98.title: Xylography
98.subtitle: The art of making woodcuts, especially for prints
98.description: The ancient text was illustrated with intricate examples of xylography.

99.title: Yore
99.subtitle: Of long ago or former times (used in nostalgic or archaic contexts)
99.description: In days of yore, knights rode on horseback to rescue princesses.

100.title: Zestful
100.subtitle: Full of zest; enthusiastic
100.description: She approached every new challenge with zestful energy.

101.title: Acumen
101.subtitle: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain
101.description: Her business acumen was evident in her successful ventures.

102.title: Bombast
102.subtitle: High-sounding language with little meaning, used to impress people
102.description: The politician's speech was full of empty bombast and lacked substance.

103.title: Circumlocution
103.subtitle: The use of many words where fewer would do, especially in a deliberate attempt to be vague or evasive
103.description: His answer was full of circumlocution, avoiding a direct response to the question.

104.title: Disingenuous
104.subtitle: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does
104.description: Her innocent questions seemed disingenuous to those who knew her true intentions.

105.title: Efficacious
105.subtitle: Producing a desired or intended result; effective
105.description: The new medication proved to be highly efficacious in treating the illness.

106.title: Fecund
106.subtitle: Producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; fertile
106.description: The fecund imagination of the author produced a continuous stream of novels.

107.title: Glabrous
107.subtitle: (especially of a plant or animal) having no hairs or other covering; smooth
107.description: The newborn kitten had surprisingly glabrous skin.

108.title: Hapless
108.subtitle: Unfortunate
108.description: The hapless traveler missed his flight and lost his luggage on the same day.

109.title: Imbroglio
109.subtitle: An extremely confused, complicated, or embarrassing situation
109.description: The political scandal created an international imbroglio.

110.title: Jubilant
110.subtitle: Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph
110.description: The fans were jubilant after their team won the championship in overtime.

111.title: Kitsch
111.subtitle: Art, objects, or design considered to be in poor taste because of excessive garishness or sentimentality, but sometimes appreciated in an ironic or knowing way
111.description: Her apartment was decorated with brightly colored kitsch from various tourist traps.

112.title: Laconic
112.subtitle: Using very few words
112.description: His laconic reply conveyed his disapproval without a single unnecessary word.

113.title: Malediction
113.subtitle: A magical word or phrase uttered with the intention of bringing about evil or destruction; a curse
113.description: The ancient text spoke of a powerful malediction placed upon the forbidden treasure.

114.title: Nadir
114.subtitle: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization
114.description: His health reached its nadir before he began to show signs of recovery.

115.title: Obviate
115.subtitle: Remove (a need or difficulty); avoid; prevent
115.description: Taking preventative measures can often obviate the need for more drastic interventions later.

116.title: Paltry
116.subtitle: Small or meager amount; trivial
116.description: He was paid a paltry sum for his extensive work.

117.title: Quiescent
117.subtitle: In a state or period of inactivity or dormancy
117.description: The volcano has been quiescent for centuries, but geologists are monitoring it closely.

118.title: Rapacious
118.subtitle: Aggressively greedy or grasping
118.description: The rapacious corporation exploited the natural resources without regard for the environment.

119.title: Salient
119.subtitle: Most noticeable or important
119.description: The salient features of the new phone were its improved camera and longer battery life.

120.title: Tendentious
120.subtitle: Expressing or intending to promote a particular cause or point of view, especially a controversial one
120.description: The documentary was criticized for its tendentious portrayal of historical events.

121.title: Unfettered
121.subtitle: Released from physical or intellectual restraints; unrestricted
121.description: The artist found creative freedom once he was unfettered by commercial demands.

122.title: Vacillate
122.subtitle: Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive
122.description: He tended to vacillate between two options, unable to make a firm decision.

123.title: Wane
123.subtitle: (of the moon) have a progressively smaller part of its visible surface illuminated, so that it appears to decrease in size; (of a state or feeling) decrease in vigor, power, or extent; become weaker
123.description: Her enthusiasm for the project began to wane after several setbacks.

124.title: Xeriscape
124.subtitle: A style of landscape design requiring minimal water
124.description: In drought-prone regions, xeriscape gardens are becoming increasingly popular.

125.title: Yarn
125.subtitle: Spun thread; a long or rambling story, especially one that is unlikely to be true
125.description: The old sailor spun a captivating yarn about his adventures at sea.

126.title: Zealot
126.subtitle: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals
126.description: The political zealot refused to consider any opposing viewpoints, sticking rigidly to his own.

127.title: Ameliorate
127.subtitle: Make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better
127.description: Efforts were made to ameliorate the living conditions of the refugees.

128.title: Bellicose
128.subtitle: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight
128.description: His bellicose rhetoric threatened to escalate the diplomatic crisis.

129.title: Concomitant
129.subtitle: Naturally accompanying or associated
129.description: Loss of appetite is a common concomitant of the flu.

130.title: Debilitate
130.subtitle: Make (someone) weak and infirm
130.description: The severe illness continued to debilitate the patient's strength.

131.title: Elicit
131.subtitle: Evoke or draw out (a response, answer, or fact) from someone in reaction to one's own actions or questions
131.description: The detective tried to elicit information from the reluctant witness.

132.title: Frivolous
132.subtitle: Not having any serious purpose or value
132.description: She considered his constant jokes to be frivolous and inappropriate for the serious meeting.

133.title: Gourmand
133.subtitle: A person who enjoys eating and often eats too much
133.description: As a true gourmand, he sought out the finest dining experiences around the world.

134.title: Harangue
134.subtitle: A lengthy and aggressive speech
134.description: The coach delivered a furious harangue to his team after their poor performance.

135.title: Indolent
135.subtitle: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
135.description: The cat lay in an indolent sprawl, enjoying the afternoon sun.

136.title: Juxtaposition
136.subtitle: The fact of two things being seen or placed close together with contrasting effect
136.description: The artist used the juxtaposition of vibrant colors and dark shadows to create a dramatic effect.

137.title: Kowtow
137.subtitle: Act in an excessively subservient manner; kneel and touch the ground with the forehead in worship or submission
137.description: He refused to kowtow to the demands of his tyrannical boss.

138.title: Languid
138.subtitle: Having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
138.description: The hot, humid weather made everyone feel languid and sluggish.

139.title: Maudlin
139.subtitle: Self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental, often through drunkenness
139.description: After a few drinks, he became maudlin and started reminiscing tearfully about his lost youth.

140.title: Noxious
140.subtitle: Harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant
140.description: The factory released noxious fumes into the atmosphere, causing health concerns.

141.title: Ostracize
141.subtitle: Exclude (someone) from a society or group
141.description: The other children would ostracize anyone who didn't conform to their strict rules.

142.title: Panacea
142.subtitle: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases
142.description: Many people seek a quick panacea for all their problems, but real solutions are often complex.

143.title: Quagmire
143.subtitle: A soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot; an awkward, complex, or hazardous situation
143.description: The company found itself in a financial quagmire after a series of bad investments.

144.title: Repudiate
144.subtitle: Refuse to accept or be associated with
144.description: He publicly repudiated the accusations made against him, declaring them false.

145.title: Sardonic
145.subtitle: Grimly mocking or cynical
145.description: His sardonic wit often made people uncomfortable, even when they laughed.

146.title: Tenacious
146.subtitle: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely
146.description: The climber had a tenacious grip on the rock face, refusing to let go.

147.title: Undulate
147.subtitle: Move with a smooth up-and-down motion
147.description: The fields of wheat undulated gently in the summer breeze.

148.title: Venerate
148.subtitle: Regard with great respect; revere
148.description: Many cultures continue to venerate their ancestors and ancient traditions.

149.title: Wanton
149.subtitle: (of a cruel or violent action) deliberate and unprovoked; sexually unrestrained
149.description: The vandals caused wanton destruction to the public park, defacing statues and breaking benches.

150.title: Xerophyte
150.subtitle: A plant adapted to live in dry conditions
150.description: Cacti are prime examples of xerophytes, thriving in arid desert environments.

151.title: Yoke
151.subtitle: A wooden crosspiece that is fastened over the necks of two animals and attached to a plow or cart; a burden or something that oppresses
151.description: The country struggled to cast off the yoke of oppression after decades of foreign rule.

152.title: Zeitgeist
152.subtitle: The defining spirit or mood of a particular period of history as shown by the ideas and beliefs of the time
152.description: The emergence of new technologies deeply influenced the zeitgeist of the late 20th century.

153.title: Absolve
153.subtitle: Declare (someone) free from guilt, obligation, or punishment
153.description: The jury voted to absolve him of all charges due to insufficient evidence.

154.title: Bombastic
154.subtitle: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated
154.description: The politician's speech was full of bombastic rhetoric but offered no concrete solutions.

155.title: Cacophony
155.subtitle: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
155.description: The city street was a cacophony of honking horns and shouting vendors.

156.title: Decry
156.subtitle: Publicly denounce
156.description: Environmental groups decried the government's decision to expand drilling operations.

157.title: Enervate
157.subtitle: Cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken
157.description: The long, hot journey had a truly enervating effect on the travelers.

158.title: Fervent
158.subtitle: Having or displaying a passionate intensity
158.description: She was a fervent advocate for animal rights, dedicating her life to the cause.

159.title: Glib
159.subtitle: (of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow
159.description: He offered a glib excuse that no one found believable.

160.title: Haughty
160.subtitle: Arrogantly superior and disdainful
160.description: The fashion designer's haughty demeanor made her seem unapproachable.

161.title: Impecunious
161.subtitle: Having little or no money
161.description: Despite his talent, the artist remained impecunious throughout his life.

162.title: Jocund
162.subtitle: Cheerful and lighthearted
162.description: The travelers enjoyed a jocund evening of singing and storytelling around the campfire.

163.title: Kismet
163.subtitle: Destiny; fate
163.description: They believed it was kismet that their paths crossed at such an unexpected moment.

164.title: Languor
164.subtitle: The state or feeling of tiredness or inertia
164.description: A feeling of languor settled over the city during the sweltering heatwave.

165.title: Mirth
165.subtitle: Amusement, especially as expressed in laughter
165.description: The children's faces were full of mirth as they played games in the park.

166.title: Nepotism
166.subtitle: The practice among those with power or influence of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs
166.description: The company was accused of nepotism after several family members were hired for key positions.

167.title: Opaque
167.subtitle: Not able to be seen through; not transparent
167.description: The instructions were so opaque that no one could understand what was expected of them.

168.title: Parsimonious
168.subtitle: Unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy or frugal
168.description: He was so parsimonious that he rarely bought anything new, even when he could afford it.

169.title: Querulous
169.subtitle: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner
169.description: The baby's querulous cries filled the quiet room.

170.title: Rancid
170.subtitle: (of foods containing fat or oil) smelling or tasting unpleasant as a result of being stale
170.description: The butter had gone rancid and was inedible.

171.title: Sanguine
171.subtitle: Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently difficult situation
171.description: Despite the mounting challenges, she remained sanguine about the project's success.

172.title: Tacit
172.subtitle: Understood or implied without being stated
172.description: There was a tacit agreement between them not to discuss the sensitive topic.

173.title: Unwitting
173.subtitle: Not aware of the full facts; unintentional
173.description: She became an unwitting accomplice to the crime, unaware of the illegal activities.

174.title: Vituperate
174.subtitle: Blame or insult (someone) in strong or violent language
174.description: He began to vituperate his opponent with harsh and abusive language.

175.title: Wry
175.subtitle: Using or expressing dry, especially mocking, humor
175.description: He gave a wry smile, acknowledging the irony of the situation.

176.title: Xerox
176.subtitle: A copy made using a xerographic copier; to make a xerographic copy of
176.description: She needed to Xerox the documents before the meeting.

177.title: Yuppie
177.subtitle: A young urban professional, typically working in a city and with a high disposable income
177.description: The new apartment complex was largely occupied by yuppies drawn to the vibrant city life.

178.title: Zodiacal
178.subtitle: Relating to the zodiac
178.description: He studied the zodiacal charts to understand his astrological predispositions.

179.title: Aberrant
179.subtitle: Departing from an accepted standard; diverging from the normal type
179.description: The scientist observed an aberrant cell growth that warranted further investigation.

180.title: Bilk
180.subtitle: Obtain or withhold money from (someone) by deceit or without justification; cheat or defraud
180.description: The con artist managed to bilk several investors before being caught.

181.title: Conjecture
181.subtitle: An opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information
181.description: The police report was based largely on conjecture rather than concrete evidence.

182.title: Diffident
182.subtitle: Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence
182.description: She was diffident about expressing her opinions in the group discussion.

183.title: Enigmatic
183.subtitle: Difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious
183.description: The artist's painting had an enigmatic quality that fascinated viewers.

184.title: Flamboyant
184.subtitle: Tending to attract attention because of their exuberance, confidence, and stylishness
184.description: He was known for his flamboyant fashion sense and dramatic stage presence.

185.title: Gratuitous
185.subtitle: Uncalled for; lacking good reason; unwarranted
185.description: The movie contained a lot of gratuitous violence that added nothing to the plot.

186.title: Hyperbole
186.subtitle: Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally
186.description: His description of the party as 'the most epic event ever' was pure hyperbole.

187.title: Idyllic
187.subtitle: Extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque
187.description: They spent an idyllic summer vacation in a charming countryside cottage.

188.title: Jejune
188.subtitle: Naive, simplistic, and superficial; dry and uninteresting
188.description: His arguments were rather jejune and failed to address the complexity of the issue.

189.title: Knell
189.subtitle: The sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral; the end or downfall of something
189.description: The announcement of the factory's closure sounded the death knell for the small town's economy.

190.title: Lamentable
190.subtitle: (of circumstances or conditions) deplorable or regrettable
190.description: The living conditions in the refugee camp were truly lamentable.

191.title: Mendacious
191.subtitle: Not telling the truth; lying
191.description: The politician was accused of making mendacious statements during the campaign.

192.title: Noxious
192.subtitle: Harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant
192.description: The factory released noxious chemicals into the river, causing environmental damage.

193.title: Ostracism
193.subtitle: Exclusion from a society or group
193.description: She faced social ostracism after her controversial opinions became known.

194.title: Parsimony
194.subtitle: Extreme unwillingness to spend money or use resources
194.description: His extreme parsimony meant he rarely enjoyed any luxuries.

195.title: Quirk
195.subtitle: A peculiar behavioral habit
195.description: One of his many quirks was his habit of talking to himself while working.

196.title: Rampant
196.subtitle: (especially of something unwelcome or unpleasant) flourishing or spreading unchecked
196.description: Corruption was rampant throughout the government at that time.

197.title: Scofflaw
197.subtitle: A person who flouts the law, especially by failing to comply with a law that is difficult to enforce effectively
197.description: Parking regulations were constantly ignored by local scofflaws.

198.title: Tenuous
198.subtitle: Very weak or slight
198.description: The connection between the two events was rather tenuous, based on speculation.

199.title: Unkempt
199.subtitle: Having an untidy or disheveled appearance
199.description: He arrived at the interview looking surprisingly unkempt.

200.title: Verdant
200.subtitle: (of countryside) green with grass or other rich vegetation
200.description: The hills were lush and verdant after the heavy spring rains.

201.title: Wistful
201.subtitle: Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing
201.description: He looked out at the old playground with a wistful expression, remembering his childhood.

202.title: Xenial
202.subtitle: Relating to or denoting the hospitality shown to guests or strangers
202.description: The locals were known for their xenial nature, always welcoming visitors warmly.

203.title: Yearn
203.subtitle: Have an intense longing for something
203.description: She began to yearn for a simpler life, away from the city's hustle and bustle.

204.title: Zestfully
204.subtitle: With great enthusiasm and energy
204.description: He tackled the new project zestfully, eager to prove himself.

205.title: Abrogate
205.subtitle: Repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement)
205.description: The parliament voted to abrogate the outdated law.

206.title: Beguile
206.subtitle: Charm or enchant (someone), sometimes in a deceptive way
206.description: He was beguiled by her beauty and charming personality, completely falling under her spell.

207.title: Chasm
207.subtitle: A deep fissure in the earth's surface; a profound difference between people, viewpoints, feelings, etc.
207.description: There was a vast chasm between their political ideologies, making compromise impossible.

208.title: Dilettante
208.subtitle: A person who cultivates an area of interest, such as the arts, without real commitment or knowledge
208.description: He was a mere dilettante in the world of classical music, lacking deep understanding or skill.

209.title: Emaciated
209.subtitle: Abnormally thin or weak, especially because of illness or lack of food
209.description: The rescued stray dog was severely emaciated, just skin and bones.

210.title: Fissure
210.subtitle: A long, narrow opening or crack in something, especially a rock or earth
210.description: A deep fissure appeared in the road after the recent earthquake.

211.title: Goad
211.subtitle: Provoke or annoy (someone) to stimulate some action or reaction
211.description: He tried to goad her into arguing, but she refused to take the bait.

212.title: Halcyon
212.subtitle: Denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy and peaceful
212.description: She often reminisced about the halcyon days of her youth, carefree and joyful.

213.title: Inexorable
213.subtitle: Impossible to stop or prevent
213.description: The inexorable march of technological progress continues unabated.

214.title: Jejune
214.subtitle: Naive, simplistic, and superficial; dry and uninteresting
214.description: His theories were so jejune that they were quickly dismissed by the scientific community.

215.title: Kitsch
215.subtitle: Art, objects, or design considered to be in poor taste because of excessive garishness or sentimentality, but sometimes appreciated in an ironic or knowing way
215.description: The souvenir shop was full of kitsch items, brightly colored and overly sentimental.

216.title: Languid
216.subtitle: Having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
216.description: The warm, lazy afternoon made him feel wonderfully languid.

217.title: Maudlin
217.subtitle: Self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental, often through drunkenness
217.description: The old movie became rather maudlin towards the end, with excessive sentimental scenes.

218.title: Niche
218.subtitle: A comfortable or suitable position in life or employment; a specialized segment of the market for a particular kind of product or service
218.description: She found her perfect niche working with rare books.

219.title: Opulent
219.subtitle: Rich and luxurious or lavish
219.description: The palace was decorated with opulent furnishings and shimmering gold accents.

220.title: Piquant
220.subtitle: Having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavor; pleasantly stimulating or exciting to the mind
220.description: The lemon zest added a delightful piquant note to the dessert.

221.title: Quixotic
221.subtitle: Extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
221.description: His quixotic attempts to solve all the world's problems seemed destined to fail.

222.title: Rapacious
222.subtitle: Aggressively greedy or grasping
222.description: The rapacious landlord continually raised the rent without justification.

223.title: Salubrious
223.subtitle: Health-giving; healthy
223.description: The clean mountain air provided a salubrious environment for recovery.

224.title: Tractable
224.subtitle: Easy to control or influence
224.description: The previously unruly students became surprisingly tractable under the new teacher's guidance.

225.title: Unctuous
225.subtitle: Excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily
225.description: The politician's unctuous compliments were clearly insincere and aimed at gaining votes.

226.title: Vignette
226.subtitle: A brief evocative description, account, or episode
226.description: The author used short, poignant vignettes to tell the story of a lifetime.

227.title: Wane
227.subtitle: (of a state or feeling) decrease in vigor, power, or extent; become weaker
227.description: The public's interest in the scandal began to wane after a few weeks.

228.title: Xenophobia
228.subtitle: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries
228.description: The rise of nationalism often correlates with an increase in xenophobia.

229.title: Yodel
229.subtitle: A form of singing or calling in which the voice rapidly changes between the normal chest voice and the high falsetto
229.description: The sound of a lone yodel echoed through the Swiss Alps.

230.title: Zillion
230.subtitle: An indefinitely large number
230.description: He claimed he had a zillion things to do before the deadline.

231.title: Ameliorate
231.subtitle: Make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better
231.description: The new policies aim to ameliorate the economic hardship faced by many families.

232.title: Brocade
232.subtitle: A rich fabric, typically silk, woven with a raised pattern, typically with gold or silver thread
232.description: The theatre curtains were made of heavy, crimson brocade.

233.title: Chicanery
233.subtitle: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose
233.description: The trial revealed years of financial chicanery by the company's executives.

234.title: Disingenuous
234.subtitle: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does
234.description: His feigned ignorance was so disingenuous it was almost insulting.

235.title: Eschew
235.subtitle: Deliberately avoid using; abstain from
235.description: True minimalists strive to eschew all unnecessary possessions.

236.title: Foment
236.subtitle: Instigate or stir up (an undesirable or violent sentiment or course of action)
236.description: The agitators sought to foment unrest among the striking workers.

237.title: Gaffe
237.subtitle: An unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment to its originator; a blunder
237.description: The diplomat's cultural gaffe caused an international incident.

238.title: Harbinger
238.subtitle: A person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another
238.description: The unusually warm weather was a harbinger of an early spring.

239.title: Imperturbable
239.subtitle: Unable to be upset or excited; unflustered
239.description: Despite the chaos around him, the pilot remained remarkably imperturbable.

240.title: Jargon
240.subtitle: Special words or expressions used by a particular profession or group and difficult for others to understand
240.description: The medical report was filled with technical jargon that was incomprehensible to the average person.

241.title: Kismet
241.subtitle: Destiny; fate
241.description: She felt it was pure kismet that they met on that particular day.

242.title: Languor
242.subtitle: The state or feeling of tiredness or inertia
242.description: A sense of peaceful languor enveloped them as they rested by the lake.

243.title: Mirthful
243.subtitle: Full of mirth; merry or amusing
243.description: The children's mirthful laughter echoed through the house.

244.title: Nepotism
244.subtitle: The practice among those with power or influence of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs
244.description: Accusations of nepotism plagued the new administration, as several family members were given high-ranking positions.

245.title: Opportune
245.subtitle: Well-chosen or particularly favorable or appropriate
245.description: The rain came at an opportune moment, saving the wilting crops.

246.title: Perfunctory
246.subtitle: (of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection
246.description: He gave a perfunctory nod of greeting, clearly not interested in conversation.

247.title: Quorum
247.subtitle: The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the proceedings of that meeting valid
247.description: The meeting couldn't proceed until a quorum of members was present.

248.title: Redolent
248.subtitle: Strongly reminiscent or suggestive of something
248.description: The old house was redolent of childhood memories, filled with familiar scents.

249.title: Scurrilous
249.subtitle: Making or spreading scandalous claims about someone with the intention of damaging their reputation
249.description: The tabloids published a scurrilous article, filled with false accusations.

250.title: Transitory
250.subtitle: Not permanent or lasting; ephemeral
250.description: Life is often described as a transitory journey, full of fleeting moments.

251.title: Unfathomable
251.subtitle: Incapable of being fully explored or understood
251.description: The depths of the human mind remain largely unfathomable.

252.title: Vitriolic
252.subtitle: Full of bitter verbal abuse or malice
252.description: She launched a vitriolic attack against her former boss, fueled by years of resentment.

253.title: Wily
253.subtitle: Skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully
253.description: The wily fox consistently outsmarted the hunters.

254.title: Xenial
254.subtitle: Relating to or denoting the hospitality shown to guests or strangers
254.description: The villagers were renowned for their xenial customs, always offering food and shelter to travelers.

255.title: Yearning
255.subtitle: A feeling of intense longing for something
255.description: He felt a deep yearning for adventure and exploration.

256.title: Zygote
256.subtitle: A diploid cell resulting from the fusion of two haploid gametes; a fertilized ovum
256.description: The development of an organism begins with a single zygote.

257.title: Arcane
257.subtitle: Understood by few; mysterious or secret
257.description: The old magician possessed arcane knowledge passed down through generations.

258.title: Banal
258.subtitle: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring
258.description: His speech was full of banal clichs, offering nothing new or insightful.

259.title: Cacography
259.subtitle: Bad handwriting or spelling
259.description: The ancient manuscript was difficult to decipher due to its cacography.

260.title: Derelict
260.subtitle: In a very poor condition as a result of disuse and neglect; a person without a home, job, or property
260.description: The abandoned building stood as a derelict reminder of better times.

261.title: Ebullience
261.subtitle: The quality of being cheerful and full of energy
261.description: Her natural ebullience made her a popular leader, inspiring everyone around her.

262.title: Farrago
262.subtitle: A confused mixture
262.description: The news report was a farrago of conflicting statements and speculation.

263.title: Glib
263.subtitle: (of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow
263.description: He had a glib answer for every difficult question, but they lacked sincerity.

264.title: Harangue
264.subtitle: A lengthy and aggressive speech
264.description: The angry crowd listened intently to the speaker's fiery harangue.

265.title: Impute
265.subtitle: Attribute or ascribe (something, especially a fault) to someone
265.description: He tried to impute the blame to his colleague, despite his own involvement.

266.title: Jejune
266.subtitle: Naive, simplistic, and superficial; dry and uninteresting
266.description: The student's essay was filled with jejune observations and lacked critical analysis.

267.title: Kudos
267.subtitle: Praise and honor received for an achievement
267.description: She received well-deserved kudos for her groundbreaking research.

268.title: Lachrymose
268.subtitle: Tearful or given to weeping
268.description: The farewell ceremony was a surprisingly lachrymose affair for everyone involved.

269.title: Miasma
269.subtitle: A noxious or poisonous atmosphere; an oppressive or unpleasant atmosphere
269.description: The old factory emitted a miasma of chemicals that polluted the air.

270.title: Nugatory
270.subtitle: Of no value or importance; useless or futile
270.description: His efforts to influence the decision were ultimately nugatory.

271.title: Obstreperous
271.subtitle: Noisy and difficult to control
271.description: The obstreperous children refused to settle down for their nap.

272.title: Panegyric
272.subtitle: A public speech or published text in praise of someone or something
272.description: The celebratory article was a beautiful panegyric to the retiring CEO.

273.title: Quisling
273.subtitle: A traitor who collaborates with an enemy occupying force
273.description: He was denounced as a quisling for his betrayal of the resistance movement.

274.title: Recalcitrant
274.subtitle: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline
274.description: The recalcitrant donkey refused to move, despite all coaxing.

275.title: Sartorial
275.subtitle: Relating to tailoring, clothes, or style of dress
275.description: His sartorial elegance was always admired at formal events.

276.title: Tergiversate
276.subtitle: Make conflicting or evasive statements; equivocate
276.description: The witness continued to tergiversate, making it difficult for the jury to believe him.

277.title: Ubiquitous
277.subtitle: Present, appearing, or found everywhere
277.description: Plastic pollution is becoming increasingly ubiquitous in our oceans.

278.title: Vituperative
278.subtitle: Bitter and abusive
278.description: The online comments section was filled with vituperative attacks.

279.title: Waggish
279.subtitle: Humorous in a playful, mischievous, or facetious manner
279.description: His waggish pranks always caused laughter, though sometimes a little annoyance.

280.title: Xanthic
280.subtitle: Yellow or yellowish
280.description: The artist used xanthic pigments to capture the warmth of the summer sun.

281.title: Yin-yang
281.subtitle: (in Chinese philosophy) two complementary principles, one feminine, dark, and negative (yin) and one masculine, bright, and positive (yang), whose interaction influences the destinies of creatures and things
281.description: The concept of yin-yang illustrates the balance of opposing forces in the universe.

282.title: Zugzwang
282.subtitle: (in chess and other games) a situation in which a player is forced to make a disadvantageous move or one that worsens their position
282.description: He felt trapped in a strategic zugzwang during the negotiation, with no favorable options.

283.title: Abstemious
283.subtitle: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking
283.description: The monk lived an abstemious life, avoiding all luxuries.

284.title: Bombast
284.subtitle: High-sounding language with little meaning, used to impress people
284.description: His speech was more bombast than substance, filled with empty promises.

285.title: Cynosure
285.subtitle: A person or thing that is the center of attention or admiration
285.description: The glittering diamond necklace became the cynosure of the entire exhibition.

286.title: Diatribe
286.subtitle: A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something
286.description: The critic launched into a furious diatribe against the director's latest film.

287.title: Effulgent
287.subtitle: Shining brightly; radiant
287.description: The morning sun was effulgent, bathing the landscape in golden light.

288.title: Fulsome
288.subtitle: Complimentary or flattering to an excessive degree; of large size or quantity
288.description: His fulsome praise for the mediocre performance seemed insincere.

289.title: Gourmand
289.subtitle: A person who enjoys eating and often eats too much
289.description: The food festival was a paradise for every true gourmand.

290.title: Hegemony
290.subtitle: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others
290.description: The emerging nation challenged the established hegemony in global trade.

291.title: Inchoate
291.subtitle: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary
291.description: The artist's early sketches were still inchoate, hinting at future masterpieces.

292.title: Jejune
292.subtitle: Naive, simplistic, and superficial; dry and uninteresting
292.description: The politician's answers to complex economic questions were surprisingly jejune.

293.title: Kakistocracy
293.subtitle: A system of government which is run by the worst, least qualified, or most unscrupulous citizens
293.description: Some citizens feared their nation was descending into a kakistocracy.

294.title: Lassitude
294.subtitle: A state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy
294.description: After the long hike, a profound sense of lassitude overcame them.

295.title: Mellifluous
295.subtitle: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear
295.description: The speaker's mellifluous voice captivated the entire audience.

296.title: Nadir
296.subtitle: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization
296.description: His business reached its nadir during the economic recession.

297.title: Obfuscate
297.subtitle: Render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
297.description: He tried to obfuscate the details of the financial transaction to avoid scrutiny.

298.title: Pecuniary
298.subtitle: Relating to or consisting of money
298.description: The divorce settlement involved complex pecuniary arrangements.

299.title: Quisling
299.subtitle: A traitor who collaborates with an enemy occupying force
299.description: History often remembers quislings with scorn and contempt.

300.title: Recalcitrant
300.subtitle: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline
300.description: The recalcitrant teenagers refused to follow the school rules.

301.title: Serendipity
301.subtitle: The occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
301.description: Their meeting was a pure act of serendipity, leading to a lifelong friendship.

302.title: Truculent
302.subtitle: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
302.description: His truculent nature often led him into unnecessary confrontations.

303.title: Unctuous
303.subtitle: Excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily
303.description: The salesperson's unctuous compliments did not convince her to buy the expensive car.

304.title: Verisimilitude
304.subtitle: The appearance of being true or real
304.description: The film achieved remarkable verisimilitude in its depiction of wartime experiences.

305.title: Weltanschauung
305.subtitle: A particular philosophy or view of life; a worldview
305.description: His travels significantly broadened his weltanschauung.

306.title: Xenial
306.subtitle: Relating to or denoting the hospitality shown to guests or strangers
306.description: The local community was known for its xenial customs, always making visitors feel at home.

307.title: Ylem
307.subtitle: (in the Big Bang theory) the primordial matter of the universe from which all later matter was formed
307.description: Cosmologists study the properties of the early universe, theorizing about the initial ylem.

308.title: Zenith
308.subtitle: The time at which something is most powerful or successful
308.description: The company reached its financial zenith last year.

309.title: Abstemious
309.subtitle: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking
309.description: He led an abstemious lifestyle, preferring simplicity over excess.

310.title: Bespoke
310.subtitle: Made for a particular customer or user
310.description: He wore a beautifully tailored bespoke suit to the wedding.

311.title: Capricious
311.subtitle: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior
311.description: Her capricious decisions often surprised her colleagues and left them scrambling.

312.title: Delineate
312.subtitle: Describe or portray (something) precisely
312.description: The artist meticulously delineated every detail of the landscape.

313.title: Egregious
313.subtitle: Outstandingly bad; shocking
313.description: His egregious error in judgment cost the company millions.

314.title: Facetious
314.subtitle: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor; flippant
314.description: His facetious remarks were ill-received during the somber meeting.

315.title: Garrulous
315.subtitle: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters
315.description: The garrulous passenger on the bus talked incessantly about her cats.

316.title: Hedonist
316.subtitle: A person who believes that the pursuit of pleasure is the most important thing in life; a pleasure-seeker
316.description: As a devoted hedonist, he sought out every opportunity for enjoyment.

317.title: Imperious
317.subtitle: Assuming power or authority without justification; arrogant and domineering
317.description: The CEO's imperious demeanor made him unpopular with his employees.

318.title: Jettison
318.subtitle: Throw or drop (something) from an aircraft or ship; abandon or discard (someone or something that is no longer wanted)
318.description: The company decided to jettison the outdated technology in favor of newer innovations.

319.title: Kinetic
319.subtitle: Relating to or resulting from motion
319.description: The dancer's performance was a display of pure kinetic energy and grace.

320.title: Labyrinthine
320.subtitle: (of a network of paths and hedges) intricate and confusing; (of a system or process) complicated and tortuous
320.description: The old castle had labyrinthine corridors where visitors often got lost.

321.title: Misanthrope
321.subtitle: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society
321.description: Despite his gruff exterior, the old misanthrope secretly cared for his neighbors.

322.title: Nefarious
322.subtitle: Wicked or criminal
322.description: The police uncovered a nefarious plot to hack into government databases.

323.title: Obsequious
323.subtitle: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree
323.description: The assistant's obsequious behavior was clearly an attempt to gain favor with the boss.

324.title: Pellucid
324.subtitle: Translucently clear; easily understood; limpid
324.description: The professor's explanation was so pellucid that even the most complex theories became clear.

325.title: Quixotic
325.subtitle: Extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
325.description: Her quixotic vision of a perfectly harmonious world was beautiful but unattainable.

326.title: Repudiate
326.subtitle: Refuse to accept or be associated with
326.description: He felt compelled to repudiate the false rumors circulating about him.

327.title: Satiate
327.subtitle: Satisfy (a desire or an appetite) to the full
327.description: No amount of food could truly satiate his hunger after weeks in the wilderness.

328.title: Tendentious
328.subtitle: Expressing or intending to promote a particular cause or point of view, especially a controversial one
328.description: The documentary's tendentious narrative left little room for dissenting opinions.

329.title: Unilateral
329.subtitle: (of an action or decision) performed or undertaken by one person or party without the agreement of another or others
329.description: The company made a unilateral decision to cut benefits, angering its employees.

330.title: Vignette
330.subtitle: A brief evocative description, account, or episode
330.description: The play was presented as a series of short, interconnected vignettes.

331.title: Wizened
331.subtitle: Shriveled or wrinkled with age
331.description: The old farmer's hands were wizened from years of working in the fields.

332.title: Xenophobe
332.subtitle: A person who has a dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries
332.description: His comments revealed him to be a deeply ingrained xenophobe.

333.title: Yawn
333.subtitle: An involuntary opening of the mouth and deep inhalation of air, usually indicating tiredness
333.description: He stifled a yawn during the boring lecture.

334.title: Zephyr
334.subtitle: A soft, gentle breeze
334.description: A warm zephyr blew in from the ocean, bringing relief from the heat.

335.title: Absurd
335.subtitle: Wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate
335.description: The idea of a talking dog was utterly absurd, but charming in the story.

336.title: Bigot
336.subtitle: A person who is intolerant toward those holding different opinions
336.description: His bigoted remarks caused offense and were widely condemned.

337.title: Conceit
337.subtitle: Excessive pride in oneself; a fanciful expression in writing or speech; an elaborate metaphor
337.description: The author used an extended conceit of a ship's journey to represent life's challenges.

338.title: Debunk
338.subtitle: Expose the falseness or hollowness of (a myth, idea, or belief)
338.description: Scientists worked to debunk the popular myth about certain foods.

339.title: Eloquent
339.subtitle: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing
339.description: Her eloquent speech captivated the audience and inspired action.

340.title: Fickle
340.subtitle: Changing frequently, especially as regards one's loyalties, interests, or affection
340.description: The weather in March is notoriously fickle, constantly shifting between sun and rain.

341.title: Glib
341.subtitle: (of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow
341.description: His glib assurances failed to convince anyone of his sincerity.

342.title: Harrowing
342.subtitle: Acutely distressing
342.description: The survivors recounted their harrowing ordeal at sea.

343.title: Idiosyncrasy
343.subtitle: A peculiarity of constitution or temperament; a distinctive or peculiar feature or characteristic of a place or thing
343.description: One of her many idiosyncrasies was her habit of wearing mismatched socks.

344.title: Jubilant
344.subtitle: Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph
344.description: The entire city was jubilant after the sports team won the championship.

345.title: Kaleidoscope
345.subtitle: A constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements; a tube with mirrors and pieces of colored glass or paper, whose reflections produce changing patterns
345.description: The city at night was a kaleidoscope of lights and colors.

346.title: Languid
346.subtitle: Having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
346.description: The hot afternoon induced a feeling of languid contentment.

347.title: Mellifluous
347.subtitle: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear
347.description: The singer's mellifluous voice filled the concert hall.

348.title: Nadir
348.subtitle: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization
348.description: After losing everything, he felt he had reached his absolute nadir.

349.title: Obfuscate
349.subtitle: Render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
349.description: The legal document was written in a way that seemed designed to obfuscate its true meaning.

350.title: Pellucid
350.subtitle: Translucently clear; easily understood; limpid
350.description: The mountain stream was so pellucid that you could see every stone at the bottom.

351.title: Querulous
351.subtitle: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner
351.description: The baby's incessant and querulous cries kept his parents awake all night.

352.title: Redolent
352.subtitle: Strongly reminiscent or suggestive of something
352.description: The scent of freshly baked bread was redolent of her grandmother's kitchen.

353.title: Sartorial
353.subtitle: Relating to tailoring, clothes, or style of dress
353.description: His sartorial elegance was always remarked upon at formal events.

354.title: Tergiversate
354.subtitle: Make conflicting or evasive statements; equivocate
354.description: When pressed for details, the politician continued to tergiversate, avoiding a direct answer.

355.title: Ubiquitous
355.subtitle: Present, appearing, or found everywhere
355.description: Mobile phones are now truly ubiquitous, found in almost every hand.

356.title: Vituperative
356.subtitle: Bitter and abusive
356.description: The vituperative comments online were harsh and uncalled for.

357.title: Waggish
357.subtitle: Humorous in a playful, mischievous, or facetious manner
357.description: His waggish remarks often brought a smile to her face, even on bad days.

358.title: Xenial
358.subtitle: Relating to or denoting the hospitality shown to guests or strangers
358.description: The small village was famous for its xenial nature, welcoming all who passed through.

359.title: Ylem
359.subtitle: (in the Big Bang theory) the primordial matter of the universe from which all later matter was formed
359.description: The concept of ylem is fundamental to understanding the universe's earliest moments.

360.title: Zephyr
360.subtitle: A soft, gentle breeze
360.description: A light zephyr provided relief on the warm afternoon, gently stirring the leaves.

361.title: Anathema
361.subtitle: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes; a formal curse by a Pope or a council of the Church
361.description: For many artists, commercialism is an anathema to pure creative expression.

362.title: Brocade
362.subtitle: A rich fabric, typically silk, woven with a raised pattern, typically with gold or silver thread
362.description: The ceremonial robes were made of heavy, intricately woven brocade.

363.title: Chicanery
363.subtitle: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose
363.description: The politician was accused of employing dirty tactics and chicanery during the election.

364.title: Disingenuous
364.subtitle: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does
364.description: His claim of ignorance was entirely disingenuous, as he was well-informed on the topic.

365.title: Eschew
365.subtitle: Deliberately avoid using; abstain from
365.description: He chose to eschew processed foods in favor of a natural, whole-food diet.
